title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #419: Limit Points of τ((n+1)!)/τ(n!)**

What is the set of limit points of the ratio τ((n+1)!)/τ(n!)?

**Status:** SOLVED (1996)
**Answer:** {1} ∪ {1 + 1/k : k ≥ 1} = {1, 2, 3/2, 4/3, 5/4, ...}
mathContext: τ(n) = divisor function = number of positive divisors of n.

title: Divisor Function τ
content:
**tau n:** The divisor function τ(n) counts the number of positive divisors of n.

τ(n) = |{d : d | n}|

For example: τ(12) = 6 since 12 has divisors 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12.

title: The Factorial Divisor Ratio
content:
**factorialDivisorRatio n:** The ratio τ((n+1)!)/τ(n!).

This measures how much the divisor count of n! increases when we multiply by n+1.

title: Legendre's Formula
content:
**legendre_formula:** vₚ(n!) = ∑_{i≥1} ⌊n/p^i⌋

The p-adic valuation of n! (highest power of p dividing n!) is the sum of floor(n/p^i) for all i.

This gives vₚ(n!) ≈ n/(p-1), so large primes divide n! with small exponent.

title: The Ratio Product Formula
content:
**ratio_product_formula:** τ((n+1)!)/τ(n!) = ∏_{p|n+1} (1 + vₚ(n+1)/(vₚ(n!)+1))

The ratio is a product over primes dividing n+1. Each factor measures how much the exponent of p increases.

title: At Most One Large Prime
content:
**at_most_one_large_prime:** At most one prime p | n+1 satisfies p > n^(2/3).

If n+1 = pk with p > n^(2/3), then k < n^(1/3) so k is 'small'. This prime dominates the ratio.

title: Small Primes Contribute ≈ 1
content:
**small_primes_contribution:** Primes p ≤ n^(2/3) contribute (1 + o(1)) to the ratio.

For small primes, vₚ(n!) is large (≈ n/p), so vₚ(n+1)/(vₚ(n!)+1) is small.

The product over all small primes is close to 1.

title: Large Prime Contributes 1 + 1/k
content:
**large_prime_contribution:** If p > n^(2/3) divides n+1 = pk, the contribution is ≈ 1 + 1/k.

For large primes, vₚ(n+1) = 1 (since p² > n+1), and the contribution simplifies to 1 + 1/(vₚ(n!)+1) ≈ 1 + 1/k.

title: The Limit Point Set
Concrete Examples
content:
**Examples of each limit point:**

- **Ratio ≈ 2:** When n+1 is prime (n+1 = p×1), ratio ≈ 1 + 1/1 = 2
- **Ratio ≈ 3/2:** When n+1 = 2p for large prime p, ratio ≈ 1 + 1/2
- **Ratio ≈ 4/3:** When n+1 = 3p for large prime p, ratio ≈ 1 + 1/3
- **Ratio ≈ 1:** When n+1 is highly composite (many small primes)

title: Sawhney's Characterization
content:
**sawhney_characterization:** The limit points are EXACTLY limitPointSet.

This is an if-and-only-if statement: x is a limit point ⟺ x ∈ {1} ∪ {1 + 1/k : k ≥ 1}.

The proof combines small/large prime analysis with density arguments.

title: Summary and Main Result
content:
**erdos_419:** SOLVED

The limit points of τ((n+1)!)/τ(n!) are exactly {1, 2, 3/2, 4/3, 5/4, ...}.

Proved by Erdős-Graham-Ivić-Pomerance (1996), independently rediscovered by Sawhney.
